subject: Re: More on parralel systems
msgSnippet: One big problem with using the letter outlines is that several of them are already braille characters. The two main criteria for the Savian alphabet contest
messageBody:
One big problem with using the letter outlines is that several of
them are already braille characters. The two main criteria for the
Savian alphabet contest were 40+ letters and little resemblance to
the Latin alphabet. Swiching values is detremental, I still have
trouble reading Cyrillic and Shavian at times.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" <tim_rice09@...>
wrote:
>
> Quite true, They and is used much more than She and Thaw is used
> more than J'ai.
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, amd64_hacker
> <amd64_hacker@> wrote:
> >
> > In the case where you end up with two letters with the same
> outline I'd
> > use the first come first serve method of sorting it out.
> > Give the letter which comes first the 'good' outline and use a
> slightly
> > modified version (with a dot raised or lowered) for the second
> letter.
> >
> > I've always liked to use a slash when I wanted to say things like
> > miles/hour, that'd be confusing in qs though.
> > Miles per hour (and most other 'per's) could be abbreviated the
> same way
> > as it is now i.e. mph would become may-pea-out.
> > If there isn't a more common word which would save more letters
> then
> > there is no reason not to use per.
> >
> > tim_rice09 wrote:
> > >
> > > I remember I made a braille copy based on Shavian letterforms.
> > > Doing the same with Quickscript would be harder since They
(the)
> and
> > > She are the same shape on an all short placement like braille.
> > > P.S. would Pea work as an abbreviation for "per"?
> > >
> > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, amd64_hacker
> > > <amd64_hacker@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > I wasn't thinking of leaving them out, I was wondering how
> best to
> > > > express quikscript in braille. :)
> > > >
> > > > Sorry for the confusion, that was my fault for mixing in an
OT
> > > gripe
> > > > about sign language.
> > > >
> > > > tim_rice09 wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Why leave Braille users out of spelling reform? With a
> phonetic
> > > > > touch reading system reading would be made much faster for
> the
> > > > > visually impared. With all 44 letters (loch, llan and the
x's
> > > > > included) there would still be 20 available blocks. Oh yea,
> > > Braille
> > > > > already has a namer dot.
> > > > >
> > > > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>
> > > > > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, amd64_hacker
> > > > > <amd64_hacker@> wrote:
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Hi,
> > > > > >
> > > > > > That is a very good point.
> > > > > > Rote learning would work up until you encounter a word
> which
> > > > > wasn't (or
> > > > > > was spelled differently) in your dictionary.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I've heard that sign languages are pretty independent of
> > > > > written/spoken
> > > > > > languages anyway, so a change of alphabet wouldn't
affect
> them.
> > > > > > It seems to me (and this is only my opinion since I
really
> > > have no
> > > > > right
> > > > > > to say one way or the other) that someone who's everyday
> > > language
> > > > > was a
> > > > > > sign language would prefer a system like SignWriting
> > > > > > <http://www.signwriting.org/
<http://www.signwriting.org/>
> > > <http://www.signwriting.org/ <http://www.signwriting.org/>>>
for
> > > > > their written materials anyway.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Braille has a near direct mapping with roman letters so
a
> new
> > > > > system
> > > > > > would be needed, any thoughts?
> > > > > >
> > > > > > btw - Sorry for being 'dead' for so long, I've been
having
> ISP
> > > > > issues.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > tim_rice09 wrote:
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > There is one area where standard spellings with any
> reform
> > > > > perposal
> > > > > > > are needed, sign language. For the hearing impared any
> > > writing
> > > > > system
> > > > > > > is ideographic since sound-spelling is impossible.
Also,
> for
> > > a
> > > > > new
> > > > > > > sign language new hand signs are needed. A braille like
> > > system is
> > > > > > > needed as well.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > >
